questions.question: A 52-year-old male, non-smoker, presents with progressive shortness of breath, persistent dry cough, and chest pain. A CT scan reveals a peripheral mass in the lower lobe of left lung, and a biopsy of the nodule demonstrates a glandular pattern with mucinous differentiation, as shown in the image below. Which of the following markers is least likely to be positive in this patient's lung lesion?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Chromogranin Explanation: Markers that are generally expressed in lung adenocarcinomas: TTF-1 (Option A) MUC1 (Option B) Napsin A (Option C) Chromogranin is a protein found in the secretory vesicles of neuroendocrine cells and is most commonly used as a marker for neuroendocrine tumours such as small-cell lung cancer . Reference: Robbins and Cotran, Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th Edition, Pages 719

questions.question: Which of the following is not an IHC marker for small-cell lung carcinoma?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Napsin A Explanation: NAPSIN A, MUC 1, and TTF 1 are the IHC (immunohistochemistry) markers for adenocarcinoma of the lung. IHC markers for small cell lung carcinoma are: Synaptophysin Chromogranin (Option B) Bombesin NSE (Neuron-Specific Enolase) (Option C) CD56 (Option D) CD57 Reference: Robbins and Cotran, Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th edition, Page 719.

questions.question: A 56-year-old male presents with persistent shoulder pain radiating to the ulnar aspect of the forearm and progressive weakness in his right hand. Examination reveals muscle wasting in the right hand. Imaging of the chest shows a mass at the apex of the right lung involving nearby neurovascular structures. Which syndrome is most likely associated with this presentation?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Horner syndrome Explanation: The patient's presentation and the presence of a lung apex mass involving nearby neurovascular structures suggests a Pancoast tumour (superior sulcus tumour) located at the apex of the lung, typically involving nearby neurovascular structures. Compression or invasion of nearby nerves, including the sympathetic chain, can result in Horner syndrome, characterised by a combination of ptosis (drooping eyelid), miosis (constricted pupil), and anhidrosis (lack of sweating) on the affected side of the face and sometimes enophthalmos (sunken appearance of the eyeball). Superior vena cava syndrome (Option B): SVC syndrome is characterised by symptoms related to compression or obstruction of the superior vena cava, typically by a tumour in the mediastinum leading to facial swelling, dilated veins, and other signs of venous congestion but not neurological manifestations. Caplan syndrome (Option C): Caplan syndrome is the combination of rheumatoid arthritis and pneumoconiosis (Coal workers' pneumoconiosis) with characteristic pulmonary nodules . It is not associated with any neurological symptoms. Carcinoid syndrome (Option D): Carcinoid syndrome is associated with symptoms such as flushing, diarrhoea, and wheezing due to the release of vasoactive substances from carcinoid tumours, and it has no association with neurological manifestations. Reference: Robbins and Cotran, Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th edition, Page 722

questions.question: A 55-year-old woman has an incidental finding of a lung mass on imaging. CT scan reveals a well-circumscribed lesion with calcifications. Biopsy revealed spindle and epithelioid cells with an eosinophilic cytoplasm, perivascular growth, and positive HMB-45 staining. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Sugar tumour (PEComa) Explanation: The clinical scenario of a well-circumscribed lung mass with calcifications and histological features of spindle and epithelioid cells with eosinophilic cytoplasm, perivascular growth pattern , and positivity for HMB-45 immunostaining is highly suggestive of a sugar tumour. It is also known as a perivascular epithelioid cell tumour (PEComa). PEComa It is a rare mesenchymal tumour . It can lead to cystic, emphysema-like dilation of terminal airspaces and obstruction of lymphatic vessels . Treatment involves surgical resection, and mTOR inhibitors are considered for un-resectable or metastatic cases. Pulmonary hamartomas (Option A): Pulmonary hamartomas are benign lung tumours of mesenchymal and epithelial components like cartilage, fat, and fibrous tissue . They are often discovered incidentally on imaging scans as small, well-defined, rounded opacities ( coin lesions ). Microscopically, they show nodules of connective tissue with epithelial clefts, often containing cartilage and lined by ciliated or non-ciliated epithelium. questions.question: A 55-year-old former shipyard worker presents with progressive dyspnea and left-sided chest pain for three months. He has a history of occupational asbestos exposure. Physical examination reveals decreased breath sounds over the left lung base. Imaging shows left-sided pleural thickening and effusion. Biopsy confirms mesothelioma. Which of the following statements is not accurate about mesothelioma and adenocarcinoma following asbesto exposure? exposure.

options.A: Adenocarcinoma often has a shorter latency period compared to mesothelioma following asbestos
options.B: Mesothelioma under electron microscopy, reveals short, non-branching microvilli.
options.C: Mesothelioma often presents with positive staining for calretinin and WT-1.
options.D: Adenocarcinoma is commonly associated with EGFR mutation.

questions.explanation: microvilli. Correct Answer: B) Mesothelioma, under electron microscopy, reveals short, non-branching microvilli. Explanation: Characteristic Malignant mesothelioma Adenocarcinoma lung Origin Arises from mesothelial cells lining the pleura. Arises from glandular epithelial cells. Association with asbestos exposure Most specific tumours due to asbestos exposure M/C carcinoma in asbestos exposure. Latency period 25-45 years after asbestos exposure 10-30 years after asbestos exposure (Option A) Specific genetic mutations NF2, BAP1, chromosome 9p deletion EGFR, ALK, KRAS (Option D) Pathological features Epithelioid, sarcomatoid, or biphasic patterns Various growth patterns, glandular differentiation Immunohistochemistry Keratin, Calretinin, WT-1 (Option C), cytokeratin 5/6, podoplanin Thyroid transcription factor-1 (TTF-1) Electron microscopy Long, slender, branching microvilli (Option B) Short and non-branching microvilli Reference: Robbins and Cotran, Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th edition, Pages 716-724

questions.question: A 55-year-old male presents with pleuritic chest pain and a pleural-based mass observed on imaging studies. Histopathological examination of a biopsy from the mass reveals spindle-shaped cells within a collagenous stroma. Which immunohistochemical marker would be most useful in differentiating solitary fibrous tumour (SFT) from mesothelioma?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) CD34 Explanation: CD34 is a marker often expressed in solitary fibrous tumours. It is most useful for identifying solitary fibrous tumours due to its high rate of positivity in SFT and its absence in mesothelioma. Characteristic Solitary Fibrous Tumor (SFT) Malignant Mesothelioma Nature of the tumour Mostly benign, rare malignant Malignant Histopathology Dense fibrous tissue, spindle cells, occasional cysts Diffuse, invasive tumour growth across the pleural surface Immunohistochemistry Positive for CD34 and STAT6. Negative for Keratin. Positive for Calretinin, WT1, cytokeratin 5/6, and podoplanin. Morphology Tumours, often pedunculated and attached to the pleural surface, may have a whorled appearance. Thick, firm, gelatinous tissue ensheathing the lung; often extensive effusion. Microscopic appearance Spindle cells are arranged in whorls among reticulin and collagen fibres. Variable : Epithelioid (tubular/papillary structures), sarcomatoid (fibrosarcoma-like), or biphasic Calretinin (Option B): Calretinin is a calcium-binding protein commonly used as a marker for mesothelioma. It is typically expressed in the epithelial and some biphasic types of mesothelioma but is not usually expressed in solitary fibrous tumours . WT1 (Wilms' tumour 1) (Option C): WT1 is another frequently positive marker in mesothelioma, particularly in epithelial mesothelioma. This marker, however, is not usually expressed in solitary fibrous tumours. TTF-1 (Thyroid transcription factor 1) (Option D): TTF-1 is primarily used to identify carcinoma of lung and thyroid origin and is not useful for distinguishing between solitary fibrous tumours and mesothelioma. TTF-1 is positive in the adenocarcinoma of the lung.

questions.question: A 45-year-old nonsmoking woman presents with a persistent cough and hemoptysis. Imaging reveals a solitary pulmonary nodule in the right lung. Biopsy shows cells with neuroendocrine features, including round to oval nuclei, stippled chromatin, and abundant granular cytoplasm arranged in nests and trabeculae. Which cell type is most likely involved in the origin of this patient's lung tumour?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Kulchitsky cells Explanation: The clinical scenario, along with biopsy features, suggest a Carcinoid tumour , a neuroendocrine tumour arising from Kulchitsky cells (Neuroendocrine cells) within the bronchial epithelium. These cells produce and secrete bioactive substances such as serotonin (5-HT) and other peptides that can influence smooth muscle contraction, immune responses, and other physiological processes. Type II pneumocytes (Option A): Type II pneumocytes are surfactant-producing cells in the alveoli and are associated with adenocarcinoma rather than carcinoid tumours. Clara cells (Option B): Clara cells are non-ciliated cells found in the bronchioles and are not involved in the origin of bronchial carcinoid tumours. These cells secrete proteins and lipids that maintain and protect the airway epithelium. Alveolar macrophages (Option D): Alveolar macrophages are immune cells responsible for phagocytosis within the alveoli and are not related to the development of carcinoid tumours. Reference: Robbins and Cotran, Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th edition, Page 724

questions.question: A 50-year-old female presents with a chronic cough and recurrent episodes of wheezing. Bronchoscopy reveals a "coat button lesion" within the bronchus, as shown in the image. Biopsy of the lesion shows nesting of cells with uniform round nuclei and moderate eosinophilic cytoplasm. What is the most likely diagnosis based on the described features?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Bronchial carcinoid tumor Explanation: The features described in the scenario suggest bronchial carcinoid tumour, a neuroendocrine tumour of bronchial epithelium characterised by nesting of cells with uniform round nuclei, moderate eosinophilic cytoplasm , and the characteristic "salt and pepper" appearance of chromatin within the nuclei. Typical carcinoids exhibit <2 mitoses per 10 high-power fields and lack necrosis. Atypical carcinoids may show 2-10 mitoses per 10 high-power fields and/or foci of necrosis. Characteristic Small Cell Carcinoma (Option A) Squamous Cell Carcinoma (Option B) Carcinoid Tumor (Option C) Adenocarcinoma (Option D) Origin Neuroendocrine cells of the lung. Squamous cells of the lung. Neuroendocrine cells of bronchial epithelium. Glandular cells of the lung. Cells in histopathology Small, round to oval, blue cells with scant cytoplasm and finely granular chromatin with a “salt and pepper” appearance. questions.question: A 50-year-old heavy smoker presents with a persistent cough and unintentional weight loss. Imaging shows a right lung mass with mediastinal lymphadenopathy. Biopsy reveals small, round cells with scant cytoplasm and nuclei exhibiting a salt-and-pepper chromatin pattern. Immunohistochemistry (IHC) is positive for neuroendocrine markers. Which of the following features is incorrectly associated with this clinical condition?

options.A: Both glandular and squamous differentiation are seen
options.B: Encrustation of tumour cells along the blood vessels with DNA material
options.C: Presence of dense neurosecretory granules on electron microscopy

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Both glandular and squamous differentiation are seen Explanation: The clinical presentation and histological features described suggest small-cell lung carcinoma, a highly malignant neuroendocrine tumour with a strong relationship to cigarette smoking. Small cell lung cancer (SCLC) primarily exhibits neuroendocrine characteristics without the glandular histological features seen in adenocarcinoma or the squamous differentiation seen in squamous cell carcinoma. Encrustation of tumour cells along the blood vessels with DNA material(Option B) The encrustation of necrotic tumour cells along the blood vessels with DNA material causes basophilic staining of vascular walls . It is known as the ‘Azzopardi effect’ , a characteristic feature often observed in Small-cell lung carcinoma. Presence of dense neurosecretory granules on electron microscopy (Option C): Small-cell lung carcinoma shows neuroendocrine differentiation and dense neurosecretory granules on electron microscopy. High proliferative index (Option D): Small-cell lung carcinoma is known for its aggressive behaviour and rapid growth, both clinically and histologically. This is reflected in a high proliferative index, with many cells in active cell cycle phases.

questions.question: A 45-year-old female presents progressive shortness of breath, especially on exertion, fatigue, and ankle swelling. Physical examination reveals elevated jugular venous pressure. Echocardiography shows right ventricular hypertrophy and elevated pulmonary artery pressure. Which of the following conditions can predispose her to this condition?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) All the above Explanation: The patient's clinical presentation with symptoms of exertional dyspnea, signs of right heart failure (elevated jugular venous pressure, right ventricular hypertrophy), and echocardiographic evidence of elevated pulmonary artery pressure suggest the presence of pulmonary hypertension. Pulmonary hypertension results from vascular remodelling and vasoconstriction in the pulmonary arterioles, leading to increased pulmonary vascular resistance and elevated pulmonary arterial pressure. Manifestations include exertional dyspnea, fatigue, chest pain, syncope, right heart failure with jugular venous distension, and peripheral oedema. Causes of Pulmonary hypertension Primary Pulmonary Hypertension (Idiopathic) Secondary Pulmonary Hypertension High altitude (Chronic hypoxia) (Option A) Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease (COPD) Interstitial lung disease (e.g., Pulmonary fibrosis) Left Heart Failure (e.g. Mitral stenosis, Systolic dysfunction) Recurrent thromboembolism events (Pulmonary embolism) (Option B) Autoimmune diseases (e.g. Systemic sclerosis) (Option C) Congenital Heart Disease (e.g. Atrial Septal Defect; Eisenmenger Syndrome) Obstructive Sleep apnea High altitude (Option A): Living at high altitudes with reduced oxygen can lead to pulmonary hypertension as: Recurrent thromboembolic events (Option B): Repeated pulmonary embolisms can obstruct blood vessels in the lungs, increasing pulmonary vascular resistance and causing pulmonary hypertension. Scleroderma (Option C): Scleroderma or Systemic Sclerosis can lead to lung vessel fibrosis and narrowing, raising pulmonary vascular resistance and contributing to pulmonary hypertension. Reference: Robbins and Cotran, Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th edition, Page 702

questions.question: A 59-year-old heavy smoker presents with loss of appetite and a persistent cough for the past few months. Imaging reveals a central lung mass involving the right bronchus and mediastinal lymph nodes. Immunohistochemical staining of a lung mass biopsy is positive for chromogranin and synaptophysin. Which set of genes is most likely involved in the underlying pathology of this patient's condition? P53 RB L-myc
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) 1,2,3 Explanation: The patient's clinical presentation and positive staining for neuroendocrine markers such as Chromogranin and synaptophysin are highly suggestive of Small-cell lung cancer (SCLC) originating from neuroendocrine cells. It is a highly malignant form of lung cancer associated with smoking and is known for its aggressive behaviour and early metastasis. The genetic landscape of SCLC typically involves the inactivation of TP53 and RB genes. L-MYC amplification is a common feature in some SCLC cases, contributing to the tumour's rapid growth and aggressive nature. Reference: Robbins and Cotran, Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th edition, Page 717

questions.question: A 57-year-old male smoker with a persistent cough and weight loss is found to have a lung mass on imaging. The biopsy showed keratin pearls and intercellular bridges. Which of the following paraneoplastic syndromes is highly associated with this diagnosis?

options.B: Syndrome of Inappropriate Antidiuretic Hormone Secretion (SIADH)

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Hypercalcemia Explanation: The given clinical presentation and histological findings point towards the diagnosis of squamous cell carcinoma, one of the major subtypes of non-small cell lung cancer, which typically arises from the central bronchi and can cause symptoms like coughing, chest pain, and hemoptysis. Hypercalcemia is the most common paraneoplastic syndrome associated with squamous cell carcinoma of the lung. SCC of the lung can produce parathyroid hormone-related protein (PTHrP) , leading to elevated calcium levels in the blood. This condition is characterised by symptoms such as fatigue, confusion, excessive thirst and urination, and nausea. Type of Lung Carcinoma Paraneoplastic Syndrome Squamous cell carcinoma Hypercalcemia Adenocarcinoma Migratory thrombophlebitis ( Trousseau syndrome ) Small cell or oat cell Carcinoma SIADH (syndrome of inappropriate anti-diuretic hormone secretion) Cushing's syndrome Lambert eaton syndrome Large cell carcinoma Gynaecomastia Syndrome of Inappropriate Antidiuretic Hormone Secretion

questions.question: A 67-year-old male smoker presents with a persistent cough and weight loss. Imaging reveals a lung mass in the upper lobe of the right lung. The biopsy reveals typical features, including keratin pearls, intercellular bridges, and nests of malignant squamous cells with abundant eosinophilic cytoplasm. Based on this scenario, which of the following statements is incorrect?

options.A: Keratin pearls are not seen in poorly differentiated squamous cell carcinoma.
options.B: p40 is the best marker for squamous cell carcinoma.
options.C: Squamous dysplasia is a precursor lesion of squamous cell carcinoma
options.D: The squamous cell carcinoma described is likely a peripheral lung lesion.

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) The squamous cell carcinoma described is likely a peripheral lung lesion. often originating in the major bronchi near the hilum. It can cause symptoms by obstructing airways. Histopathologically, it is characterised by keratin pearls, intercellular bridges, and nests of malignant squamous cells with abundant eosinophilic cytoplasm. Location of lung carcinomas: Central: Squamous cell carcinoma, Small cell carcinoma and Bronchial carcinoids. Peripheral: Adenocarcinoma and Large-cell carcinoma. Keratin pearls are not seen in poorly differentiated squamous cell carcinoma (Option A): Keratin pearls are a characteristic feature of well-differentiated squamous cell carcinoma p40 is the best marker for squamous cell carcinoma (Option B): p40 is the most specific and best marker for squamous cell carcinoma Squamous dysplasia is a recognised precursor lesion for squamous cell carcinoma (Option C): Squamous cell carcinomas often arise from pre-existing bronchial epithelial conditions such as squamous metaplasia or dysplasia. Reference: Robbins and Cotran, Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th edition, Page 717

questions.question: A 58-year-old male smoker presents with a persistent cough and mild shortness of breath. Chest imaging reveals a solitary pulmonary nodule. A biopsy is performed, and a histopathological examination of the lung tissue is shown in the image below. What is the most likely diagnosis?

options.D: Diffuse idiopathic pulmonary neuroendocrine cell hyperplasia

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Adenocarcinoma in situ Explanation: The histopathological image shows a localised proliferation of dysplastic cells along pre-existing alveolar septa, indicative of adenocarcinoma in situ (AIS) or bronchioloalveolar carcinoma which is a precancerous lesion of adenocarcinoma of the lung with severe cytologic atypia . AIS is an early stage of lung cancer where abnormal glandular cells are confined to the airway lining without invasion and exhibit a “lepidic growth pattern” (or butterfly on fence pattern), spreading along intact alveolar structures without invasion. Lesions are usually small, measuring ≤ 3 cm. Carcinoma in situ (Option A): Carcinoma in situ involves abnormal squamous cells confined to the epithelium without invading the surrounding structures. Adenomatous hyperplasia (Option B): Atypical adenomatous hyperplasia (AAH) is a precursor lesion of lung adenocarcinoma with mild cytologic atypia, characterised by dysplastic pneumocytes lining alveolar walls. questions.question: A 55-year-old male smoker presents to the clinic with chronic cough and hemoptysis. He has been smoking two packs of cigarettes per day for the past 30 years. Upon further evaluation, a biopsy reveals lung carcinoma. Which of the following statements regarding risk factors for lung carcinoma is false?

options.A: Smoking is a major risk factor for squamous cell carcinoma of the lung.
options.B: Smoking has no association with adenocarcinoma of the lung.
options.C: Smoking is a significant risk factor for small-cell lung carcinoma.
options.D: Asbestosis exposure, along with smoking, multiplies the risk of lung cancer.

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Smoking has no association with adenocarcinoma of the lung. Explanation: Smoking significantly increases the risk of adenocarcinoma of the lung, although to a lesser extent than other types. Adenocarcinoma, commonly found in non-smokers, can still occur due to tobacco smoking. It often involves mutations in growth factor receptor pathways and is the most prevalent subtype in non-smokers. Smoking is a major risk factor for squamous cell carcinoma of the lung (Option A): Smoking significantly increases the risk of squamous cell carcinoma of the lung as it has a strong association, resulting in chromosomal deletions involving tumour suppressor loci involving 3p,9p and 17p. Smoking is a significant risk factor for small-cell lung carcinoma (Option C): Small-cell carcinoma is almost always linked to smoking, exhibiting the highest mutation rate among lung cancers. SCLC is almost exclusively caused by smoking and usually involves the inactivation of both TP53 and RB genes. Asbestosis exposure, along with smoking, multiplies the risk of lung cancer (Option D): Asbestos exposure, especially when combined with smoking, significantly raises the risk of lung cancer . Non-smokers exposed to asbestos have a five-fold higher risk, while smokers have a 55-fold increased risk compared to non-smokers. Reference: Robbins and Cotran, Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th edition, Pages 716, 717

questions.question: A 55-year-old man presents with severe shortness of breath, cough, and fever after recent bacterial pneumonia. Physical examination shows tachypnea, hypoxia, and diffuse crackles on chest auscultation. Chest X-ray reveals bilateral opacities suggestive of pulmonary oedema. Histopathological examination of lung biopsy shows congested, edematous lungs with inflammation. Which histopathological finding is characteristic of the acute exudative stage in this patient's lung injury?

options.B: Formation of fibrotic thickening in the alveolar septa
options.C: Presence of waxy hyaline membranes lining the alveolar walls
options.D: Resolution of granulation tissue in the alveolar spaces

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Presence of waxy hyaline membranes lining the alveolar walls Explanation: In the acute exudative stage of lung injury, such as acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) triggered by bacterial pneumonia, lungs exhibit characteristic waxy hyaline membranes lining the alveolar walls. These membranes comprise fibrin-rich oedema fluid mixed with remnants of necrotic epithelial cells, representing a hallmark feature of acute lung injury and ARDS. Pathological changes seen in acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) Stage Features 1. Acute Exudative Stage Lungs appear heavy, firm, red, and boggy. Manifestations include congestion, interstitial and intra-alveolar oedema, inflammation, fibrin deposition, and diffuse alveolar damage. Alveolar walls are lined with “waxy hyaline membranes” composed of fibrin-rich oedema fluid mixed with remnants of necrotic epithelial cells. 2. Proliferative or Organizing Stage Proliferation of Type II pneumocytes. Granulation tissue forms in the alveolar walls and spaces. 3. Late Fibrotic Stage Fibrotic thickening of alveolar septa indicates persistent fibrosis and scarring that may develop in some cases of lung injury.

questions.question: Which of the following statements regarding the pathogenesis sequence of non-cardiogenic pulmonary oedema (NCPE) and acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) is incorrect? Endothelial activation is the hallmark of pathogenesis. Release of cytokines by alveolar epithelial cells Macrophage activation resulting in the release of IL-8 and TNF Recruitment of lymphocytes by IL-8
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) 2 and 4 Explanation: In ARDS, cytokines are released by endothelial cells, not alveolar epithelial cells, and IL-8 causes the recruitment of neutrophils, not lymphocytes. Pathogenesis of non-cardiogenic pulmonary oedema (NCPE) and acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS): The hallmark of pathogenesis is ‘endothelial activation’ by bacteria leads to cytokine release, promoting neutrophil adhesion to blood vessels and subsequent endothelial damage. This process results in blood/plasma leakage into the interstitial space and alveoli, causing non-cardiogenic pulmonary oedema (NCPE). Activated macrophages release IL-8 and TNF , recruiting more neutrophils into the alveoli. They also release proteases and free radicals, which damage type 1 and type 2 pneumocytes. This impairs gas exchange and surfactant production, contributing to lung dysfunction.

questions.question: A 45-year-old woman presents with progressive shortness of breath and fatigue. On examination, she has elevated jugular venous pressure and a loud pulmonary component of the second heart sound. Echocardiography reveals right ventricular hypertrophy and dilation. Which of the following statements is correct regarding the vascular changes of this condition?

options.A: BMPR2 mutations result in endothelial and vascular smooth muscle cell apoptosis.
options.B: Classic atherosclerotic changes are commonly observed in pulmonary arteries.
options.C: Plexiform lesions are early changes of pulmonary hypertension.
options.D: Pulmonary arterioles show medial hypertrophy and intimal fibrosis, narrowing the lumens.

questions.explanation: the lumens. Correct Answer: D) Pulmonary arterioles show medial hypertrophy and intimal fibrosis, narrowing the lumens. Explanation: The patient's clinical presentation with symptoms of right heart failure, elevated jugular venous pressure, and findings of right ventricular hypertrophy and dilation on echocardiography suggest pulmonary hypertension. Histopathologically, pulmonary hypertension is characterised by the remodelling of pulmonary arterioles, which typically exhibit medial hypertrophy (thickening of the smooth muscle layer) and intimal fibrosis. These changes lead to the narrowing of the vessel lumens, increased pulmonary vascular resistance, and subsequent right heart strain. BMPR2 mutations result in endothelial and vascular smooth muscle cell apoptosis. (Option A): BMPR2 mutations are associated with familial pulmonary arterial hypertension, commonly associated with dysregulation of endothelial and vascular cellular processes involved in vascular homeostasis, including aberrant proliferation and resistance to apoptosis. Classic atherosclerotic changes are commonly observed in pulmonary arteries. (Option B): Classic atherosclerotic changes, such as plaque formation and lipid deposition, are not typical findings in pulmonary arteries affected by pulmonary hypertension. Plexiform lesions are early changes of pulmonary hypertension. (Option C): Plexiform lesions are characterised by tufts of capillary formations that are more specific to certain types of pulmonary hypertension, particularly in idiopathic and familial cases. Plexiform lesions of small arteries are characteristic of advanced pulmonary hypertension rather than early changes.
